attributes.title: Social and psychological impact of the COVID-19 crisis on a swiss student population
attributes.description: Analyses of the Swiss StudentLife data during parts of the COVID-19 crisis

q1.value: Timon Elmer, Kieran Mepham, Christoph Stadtfeld

q2.value:
Research Questions

Social impact:
1. How are social networks of students affected by the COVID-19 crisis? 
Analyses:
Within-person comparisons of network descriptives (with StudentLife2 wave 10, collected in September 2019)
Between-cohort comparisons of network descriptives (with StudentLife1 wave12, collected at about the same time in 2019)

H1. Students nominate fewer others in multiple dimensions of their social networks (e.g., friendship, co-study) in (a) within-person comparisons and (b) between-cohort comparisons. 

H1b: Ties that are maintained during the crisis are those that were stronger in the previous wave (i.e., those are characterized by an overlap in multiple relational dimensions).


Psychological impact:
2. How is mental health of students affected by the COVID-19 crisis? 

H2. Some aspects of student's mental health will improve (e.g., less stress) while others will decrease (e.g., higher loneliness). 

Analyses:
 Within-person comparisons (with SudentLife2 wave 10)
Between-cohort comparisons (with SudentLife1 wave 12)

3. Which social factors during the COVID-19 crisis are associated with mental health?  (exploratory)
Analysis: New ego-network items

All analyses will be descriptive and exploratory.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Students will be surveyed during the COVID-19 crisis in Switzerland. Measures of self-reported social networks and mental health will be compared within-person (with previous wave) and between-cohort (data of a cohort that was measured a year earlier at the same time)

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value: For question 1.2 We will compare our new data, not yet collected, to old data. Old data here is both data from past timepoints of the same cohort of students, and data from another cohort of students. We have analyzed various aspects of this data in previous projects.

question.value: Participants will be recruited trough their institutional email address and will only contain individuals of two specific study programs. Participants will be paid 30CHF for the 60min survey.

q11.value:
Cohort N1 = 261, Cohort N2 = 660. Old comparison cohort N3 = ?
size of the sample will be lower because some students might indicate that they quit the study program by now.

q12.value: Participants will only contain individuals of two specific study programs.

q13.value: the data collection ends after 1 week

question.value:
Social networks: Name generator items of friendship, co-study, social interactions (digital, phone, personal)
Mental health: Scales on Depression, Anxiety, Stress, Loneliness
descriptive analyses, network regression models

attributes.title: An embodied cognition approach of existential threat
attributes.description: In this exploratory preregistered study, we will test the hypothesis that thinking about death in a cold environment, compared to a hot environnement, exacerbates terror management reactions (avoidance of self-awareness and worldview defense).  This hypothesis is derived from an embodied cognition approach of terror management theory.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

dataCollectionDates.value: Data will be collected from January 23 to March 2020.

question2a.value:
The two independent variables are orthogonal. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four conditions in a 2x2 between-participants design. 

IV1: Participants will be randomly assigned to a mortality salience or a control condition (exam condition). Two open-ended questions will be displayed one by one on the computer screen. Depending on the experimental condition, the two questions will be related to death or to an important exam. Participants will have to write their answers for each of the two questions directly on the computer. One question will be answered on a dark grey glossy screen reflecting the participant’s face and another question will be answered on a light grey glossy screen not reflecting the participant’s face. The two different glossy screens will be used to assess self-awareness avoidance (see hereafter). The order of the two questions and the order of the glossy screen colors (dark grey vs. light grey) will be counter-balanced across participants. 
IV2: Participants will be randomly assigned to a cold or warm room. As previously mentioned, the two rooms will be very similar except for temperature. The heater of the experimental room will be turned on or off to create a hot or a cold environment, respectively. Room temperature will be systematically monitored before and after each experimental session to make sure that the two environments differ substantially from one another in terms of temperature (targeted temperature difference = about 5 °C).

question2b.value:
DV1: The first dependent variable is a measure of self-awareness avoidance. The first DV is a composite score corresponding to the mean difference between time spent writing on a dark grey glossy screen reflecting the participant’s face and the time spent writing on a light grey glossy screen not reflecting the participant’s face (see section B. 1). Higher scores indicate that the participants spent more time looking at the computer screen when it reflects their own image than they spent time looking at the computer screen when it does not reflect their image.  

DV2: The second dependent variable is a measure of worldview defense. The responses to the 5 items used to assess the evaluation of the pro-French essay author will be averaged. In the same way, the responses to the 5 items used to assess the evaluation of the anti-French essay author will be averaged. The DV2 is the mean difference between the global evaluation of the pro- and anti- French essay author. Higher scores indicate greater preference for the pro- vs. anti- French essay author.

question10b.value:
The experiment will take place either in a cold room (no heater during winter) or a warm room (with a heater). The study will be presented as a study on personality traits (cover story). Participants will randomly be assigned to a 2 (Mortality Salience vs. Control) x 2 (Warm temperature vs. Cold temperature) between-participants design. Each of them will answer to one question while in a situation inducing self-awareness (dark grey screen covered with a transparent Plexiglas reflecting one’s face) and one question in a situation not eliciting self-awareness (light grey screen covered with a transparent Plexiglas not reflecting one’s face) and time spent for each of these situations will be subtracted to compose a score reflecting one’s avoidance of the situation eliciting self-awareness (the lower the score, the higher the motivation to escape from self-awareness). The two questions will either be related to their future death or to a future exam depending on the experimental condition. Experimenters will be blind to participants’ mortality salience condition (but not to room temperature). 
Mortality salience will be activated by two open-ended questions (e.g., Arndt et al., 1998; Greenberg, Simon, Harmon-Jones et al., 1995; Rosenblatt et al., 1989). Participants will be invited to write a short text regarding their emotions, thoughts and events related to their own death versus to an important exam. This task will be completed directly on the computer, using the keyboard to write sentences in response to the death- or exam-related questions. 
The two open-ended questions will be:

- Mortality condition: «Please briefly describe the emotions that the thought of your own death arouses in you» and «Jot down, as specifically as you can, what you think will happen to you physically as you die and once you are physically dead». 
OR 
- Exam condition: «Please briefly describe the emotions that the thought of an important exam arouses in you» and «Jot down, as specifically as you can, what you think will happen to you physically as you are in exam situation and once you have finished».

Self-awareness avoidance. We will assess self-awareness avoidance by using the reflection of the participant’s face on a dark grey (vs. Light grey) screen covered with a piece of Plexiglas (see https://osf.io/sp6nc/). Covering the surface of the screen with a piece of Plexiglas can turn the screen into a reflective mirror-like surface when the background color is dark, but not when using a light-colored background color. The Plexiglas will be totally integrated to the screen to reduce any suspicion from participants. We will use block randomization for background color, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two blocks: either light-dark, or dark-light.

Delay. The PANAS-X is a questionnaire used to measure positive and negative affects (e.g., Watson & Clark, 1994). This scale will be used as delay task, a distractor task to obtain a delay between mortality exposure and World View Defense Questionnaire. Research and theorizing suggests that worldview defense is larger after a delay (Burke, Martens, & Faucher, 2010). 

World View Questionnaire. The worldview defense measure will consist of two texts displaying opposite opinions regarding the French values (e.g. Burke et al., 2010). These two opposite worldviews will then be rated by the participant on 5 items (7-points scales) to assess the participant’s agreement with the essay and the participant’s likeability of the author of the essay.

For the research materials (experiment script and worldview questionnaire), see https://osf.io/yrd8x/

question4b.value: Participants will be native French speakers.

question5b.value: Participants will be introductory students psychology from the University of Poitiers who will participate in exchange for course credits. All data will be collected with a computer, except for the worldview defense measure (paper and pencil task).

question6b.value:
Our target sample size is 200 participants (50 participants per cell). Our key prediction is an interaction between mortality salience (death thoughts vs. control thoughts) and room temperature (cold vs. warm) in a 2 x 2 analysis of variance (ANOVA). The present study is exploratory and the expected effect size is unknown. However, this sample size (N = 200) provides adequate power (80%) to detect a significant interaction (p <.05) assuming an effect size of Cohen’s d = 0.40. This small-to-moderate effect size is comparable to the mean effect size in social psychology based on a meta-meta-analysis of 100 years of research (Richard, Bond, & Stokes-Zoota, 2003).

For a file related to our power analysis, see https://osf.io/5nybp/

question7b.value: Data collection will stop when N = 200.

question8b.value:
Participants failing to answer to at least one of the two questions displayed on the computer screen will be excluded from our analyses.

A cut-off of 2.5 MAD from the median will be used to exclude outliers (Leys, Ley, Klein, Bernard, & Licata, 2013).

question9b.value: The study will be stopped and restarted if the proportion of excluded participants is greater than 20%.

question6c.value: The number of hypotheses is already determined and is limited, hence we will not use corrections for multiple tests.

question7c.value: Missing data will be omitted from our analyses by pairwise deletion.

question9c.value: We do not anticipate any data transformation.

question10c.value: If the residual distribution of our dependent variables (DV1 and DV2) differs from normality (as assessed by a Shapiro-Wilks test), we will use a non-parametric alternative to test our hypotheses, such as a Mann-Whitney test.

question1a.value:
H1) Thinking about death in a cold rather than a hot environment should exacerbate avoidance of self-awareness

H2) Thinking about death in a cold rather than a hot environment should exacerbate worldview defense

question2a.value:
H1) Participants should spend less time looking at one’s own reflection on a computer screen while writing about death (vs. an important exam), and this effect should be exacerbated in a cold compared to a hot room

H2) Thinking about death (vs. an important exam) should increase the preference for a pro- vs. anti- French essay author, and this effect should be exacerbated in a cold compared to a hot room 

For a figure describing the shape of the interactions, see https://osf.io/g7pr3/

question3a.value:
Even though our preliminary hypothesis is about self-awareness avoidance (H1), a worldview questionnaire will also be used to check whether the classic mortality salience effect is replicated (H2). Two essays reflecting opposite worldviews will be used and participants will be asked to evaluate each essay. According to terror management theory, participants in the mortality salience condition should exhibit greater preference for a pro- vs. anti- French essay author (worldview defense), compared to participants in the control condition. 

The data will be collected in France during winter (January-March 2020). Participants will be randomly assigned to a cold or a hot experimental room. The two rooms will be very similar except for temperature. The heater of the experimental room will be turned on or off to create a hot or a cold environment, respectively. Room temperature will be systematically monitored before and after each experimental session to make sure that the two environments differ substantially from one another in terms of temperature (targeted temperature difference = about 5 °C).

question5a.value: Research on terror management theory suggests that individuals tend to avoid self-awareness when their mortality is made salient (Arndt et al., 1998). This suggests that thinking about death (vs. an important exam) should reduce the time spent looking at one’s reflected image on a computer screen. In addition, embodied cognition theories (conceptual metaphor theory, Lakoff & Johnson, 1980, Landau et al., 2014) suggest that death may be more strongly associated with coldness than with warmth (a cold body is a dead body). This suggests that thinking about death should be more aversive in a cold rather than in a warm environment because a cold physical environment would facilitate the mental simulation of death. Thus, coldness (compared to warmth) should exacerbate the effects of mortality salience on self-awareness avoidance and worldview defense.

question1c.value:
Time taken to answer to each question will be collected using Psychopy2 (Peirce et al., 2019). We will compute a composite score of the time spent answering to the question associated to a dark screen minus the time spent answering to the question associated to a light screen (thus, the higher the score, the longer the time taken to write on the dark screen in comparison to the light screen).

A worldview defense score will be calculated as the preference for the pro- vs. anti- French essay in a similar manner (by subtraction).

question2c.value: We will use 2 X 2 ANOVAs to test our hypotheses. Planned comparisons will be examined using LSD tests.

question3c.value:
IV1: mortality salience (death-related thoughts vs. exam-related thoughts)
IV2: room temperature (cold vs. warm)
DV1: self-awareness avoidance (time taken to write on the dark screen in comparison to the light screen)
DV2: worldview defense (preference for the pro- vs. anti- French essay)

The experiment includes several measures aimed at determining if the intended conditions are met: the actual room temperature will be measured before and after each participant’s session to make sure that the two conditions differ significantly in terms of temperatures. Thermometer will be not visible for the participants. In addition, subjective temperature perception will be collected orally at the end of the experiment session.

The first DV is a composite score corresponding to the mean difference between time spent writing on a dark grey glossy screen reflecting the participant’s face and the time spent writing on a light grey glossy screen not reflecting the participant’s face (see section B. 1). Higher scores indicate that the participants spent more time looking at the computer screen when it reflects their own image than they spent time looking at the computer screen when it does not reflect their image.  

DV2: The second dependent variable is a measure of worldview defense. The responses to the 5 items used to assess the evaluation of the pro-French essay author will be averaged. In the same way, the responses to the 5 items used to assess the evaluation of the anti-French essay author will be averaged. The DV2 is the mean difference between the global evaluation of the pro- and anti- French essay author. Higher scores indicate greater preference for the pro- vs. anti- French essay author.

question10b.value:
The experiment will take place either in a cold room (no heater during winter) or a warm room (with a heater). The study will be presented as a study on personality traits (cover story). Participants will randomly be assigned to a 2 (Mortality Salience vs. Control) x 2 (Warm temperature vs. Cold temperature) between-participants design. Each of them will answer to one question while in a situation inducing self-awareness (dark grey screen covered with a transparent Plexiglas reflecting one’s face) and one question in a situation not eliciting self-awareness (light grey screen covered with a transparent Plexiglas not reflecting one’s face) and time spent for each of these situations will be subtracted to compose a score reflecting one’s avoidance of the situation eliciting self-awareness (the lower the score, the higher the motivation to escape from self-awareness). The two questions will either be related to their future death or to a future exam depending on the experimental condition. Experimenters will be blind to participants’ mortality salience condition (but not to room temperature). 
Mortality salience will be activated by two open-ended questions (e.g., Arndt et al., 1998; Greenberg, Simon, Harmon-Jones et al., 1995; Rosenblatt et al., 1989). Participants will be invited to write a short text regarding their emotions, thoughts and events related to their own death versus to an important exam. This task will be completed directly on the computer, using the keyboard to write sentences in response to the death- or exam-related questions. 
The two open-ended questions will be:

- Mortality condition: «Please briefly describe the emotions that the thought of your own death arouses in you» and «Jot down, as specifically as you can, what you think will happen to you physically as you die and once you are physically dead». 
OR 
- Exam condition: «Please briefly describe the emotions that the thought of an important exam arouses in you» and «Jot down, as specifically as you can, what you think will happen to you physically as you are in exam situation and once you have finished».

Self-awareness avoidance. We will assess self-awareness avoidance by using the reflection of the participant’s face on a dark grey (vs. Light grey) screen covered with a piece of Plexiglas (see https://osf.io/sp6nc/). Covering the surface of the screen with a piece of Plexiglas can turn the screen into a reflective mirror-like surface when the background color is dark, but not when using a light-colored background color. The Plexiglas will be totally integrated to the screen to reduce any suspicion from participants. We will use block randomization for background color, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two blocks: either light-dark, or dark-light.

Delay. The PANAS-X is a questionnaire used to measure positive and negative affects (e.g., Watson & Clark, 1994). This scale will be used as delay task, a distractor task to obtain a delay between mortality exposure and World View Defense Questionnaire. Research and theorizing suggests that worldview defense is larger after a delay (Burke, Martens, & Faucher, 2010). 

World View Questionnaire. The worldview defense measure will consist of two texts displaying opposite opinions regarding the French values (e.g. Burke et al., 2010). These two opposite worldviews will then be rated by the participant on 5 items (7-points scales) to assess the participant’s agreement with the essay and the participant’s likeability of the author of the essay.

For the research materials (experiment script and worldview questionnaire), see https://osf.io/yrd8x/

question4b.value: Participants will be native French speakers.

question5b.value: Participants will be introductory students psychology from the University of Poitiers who will participate in exchange for course credits. All data will be collected with a computer, except for the worldview defense measure (paper and pencil task).

question6b.value:
Our target sample size is 200 participants (50 participants per cell). Our key prediction is an interaction between mortality salience (death thoughts vs. control thoughts) and room temperature (cold vs. warm) in a 2 x 2 analysis of variance (ANOVA). The present study is exploratory and the expected effect size is unknown. However, this sample size (N = 200) provides adequate power (80%) to detect a significant interaction (p <.05) assuming an effect size of Cohen’s d = 0.40. This small-to-moderate effect size is comparable to the mean effect size in social psychology based on a meta-meta-analysis of 100 years of research (Richard, Bond, & Stokes-Zoota, 2003).

For a file related to our power analysis, see https://osf.io/5nybp/

question7b.value: Data collection will stop when N = 200.

question8b.value:
Participants failing to answer to at least one of the two questions displayed on the computer screen will be excluded from our analyses.

A cut-off of 2.5 MAD from the median will be used to exclude outliers (Leys, Ley, Klein, Bernard, & Licata, 2013).

question9b.value: The study will be stopped and restarted if the proportion of excluded participants is greater than 20%.

question6c.value: The number of hypotheses is already determined and is limited, hence we will not use corrections for multiple tests.

question7c.value: Missing data will be omitted from our analyses by pairwise deletion.

question9c.value: We do not anticipate any data transformation.

question10c.value: If the residual distribution of our dependent variables (DV1 and DV2) differs from normality (as assessed by a Shapiro-Wilks test), we will use a non-parametric alternative to test our hypotheses, such as a Mann-Whitney test.

question1a.value:
H1) Thinking about death in a cold rather than a hot environment should exacerbate avoidance of self-awareness

H2) Thinking about death in a cold rather than a hot environment should exacerbate worldview defense

question2a.value:
H1) Participants should spend less time looking at one’s own reflection on a computer screen while writing about death (vs. an important exam), and this effect should be exacerbated in a cold compared to a hot room

H2) Thinking about death (vs. an important exam) should increase the preference for a pro- vs. anti- French essay author, and this effect should be exacerbated in a cold compared to a hot room 

For a figure describing the shape of the interactions, see https://osf.io/g7pr3/

question3a.value:
Even though our preliminary hypothesis is about self-awareness avoidance (H1), a worldview questionnaire will also be used to check whether the classic mortality salience effect is replicated (H2). Two essays reflecting opposite worldviews will be used and participants will be asked to evaluate each essay. According to terror management theory, participants in the mortality salience condition should exhibit greater preference for a pro- vs. anti- French essay author (worldview defense), compared to participants in the control condition. 

The data will be collected in France during winter (January-March 2020). Participants will be randomly assigned to a cold or a hot experimental room. The two rooms will be very similar except for temperature. The heater of the experimental room will be turned on or off to create a hot or a cold environment, respectively. Room temperature will be systematically monitored before and after each experimental session to make sure that the two environments differ substantially from one another in terms of temperature (targeted temperature difference = about 5 °C).

question5a.value: Research on terror management theory suggests that individuals tend to avoid self-awareness when their mortality is made salient (Arndt et al., 1998). This suggests that thinking about death (vs. an important exam) should reduce the time spent looking at one’s reflected image on a computer screen. In addition, embodied cognition theories (conceptual metaphor theory, Lakoff & Johnson, 1980, Landau et al., 2014) suggest that death may be more strongly associated with coldness than with warmth (a cold body is a dead body). This suggests that thinking about death should be more aversive in a cold rather than in a warm environment because a cold physical environment would facilitate the mental simulation of death. Thus, coldness (compared to warmth) should exacerbate the effects of mortality salience on self-awareness avoidance and worldview defense.

question1c.value:
Time taken to answer to each question will be collected using Psychopy2 (Peirce et al., 2019). We will compute a composite score of the time spent answering to the question associated to a dark screen minus the time spent answering to the question associated to a light screen (thus, the higher the score, the longer the time taken to write on the dark screen in comparison to the light screen).

A worldview defense score will be calculated as the preference for the pro- vs. anti- French essay in a similar manner (by subtraction).

question2c.value: We will use 2 X 2 ANOVAs to test our hypotheses. Planned comparisons will be examined using LSD tests.

question3c.value:
IV1: mortality salience (death-related thoughts vs. exam-related thoughts)
IV2: room temperature (cold vs. warm)
DV1: self-awareness avoidance (time taken to write on the dark screen in comparison to the light screen)
DV2: worldview defense (preference for the pro- vs. anti- French essay)

The experiment includes several measures aimed at determining if the intended conditions are met: the actual room temperature will be measured before and after each participant’s session to make sure that the two conditions differ significantly in terms of temperatures. Thermometer will be not visible for the participants. In addition, subjective temperature perception will be collected orally at the end of the experiment session.

DV1: self-awareness avoidance (time taken to write on the dark screen in comparison to the light screen)
DV2: worldview defense (preference for the pro- vs. anti- French essay)

The experiment includes several measures aimed at determining if the intended conditions are met: the actual room temperature will be measured before and after each participant’s session to make sure that the two conditions differ significantly in terms of temperatures. Thermometer will be not visible for the participants. In addition, subjective temperature perception will be collected orally at the end of the experiment session.

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun
registration_responses.dataCollectionDates: Data will be collected from January 23 to March 2020.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
H1) Thinking about death in a cold rather than a hot environment should exacerbate avoidance of self-awareness

H2) Thinking about death in a cold rather than a hot environment should exacerbate worldview defense
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a:
H1) Participants should spend less time looking at one’s own reflection on a computer screen while writing about death (vs. an important exam), and this effect should be exacerbated in a cold compared to a hot room

H2) Thinking about death (vs. an important exam) should increase the preference for a pro- vs. anti- French essay author, and this effect should be exacerbated in a cold compared to a hot room 

For a figure describing the shape of the interactions, see https://osf.io/g7pr3/
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a:
Even though our preliminary hypothesis is about self-awareness avoidance (H1), a worldview questionnaire will also be used to check whether the classic mortality salience effect is replicated (H2). Two essays reflecting opposite worldviews will be used and participants will be asked to evaluate each essay. According to terror management theory, participants in the mortality salience condition should exhibit greater preference for a pro- vs. anti- French essay author (worldview defense), compared to participants in the control condition. 

The data will be collected in France during winter (January-March 2020). Participants will be randomly assigned to a cold or a hot experimental room. The two rooms will be very similar except for temperature. The heater of the experimental room will be turned on or off to create a hot or a cold environment, respectively. Room temperature will be systematically monitored before and after each experimental session to make sure that the two environments differ substantially from one another in terms of temperature (targeted temperature difference = about 5 °C).
registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question5a: Research on terror management theory suggests that individuals tend to avoid self-awareness when their mortality is made salient (Arndt et al., 1998). This suggests that thinking about death (vs. an important exam) should reduce the time spent looking at one’s reflected image on a computer screen. In addition, embodied cognition theories (conceptual metaphor theory, Lakoff & Johnson, 1980, Landau et al., 2014) suggest that death may be more strongly associated with coldness than with warmth (a cold body is a dead body). This suggests that thinking about death should be more aversive in a cold rather than in a warm environment because a cold physical environment would facilitate the mental simulation of death. Thus, coldness (compared to warmth) should exacerbate the effects of mortality salience on self-awareness avoidance and worldview defense.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
The two independent variables are orthogonal. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four conditions in a 2x2 between-participants design. 

IV1: Participants will be randomly assigned to a mortality salience or a control condition (exam condition). Two open-ended questions will be displayed one by one on the computer screen. Depending on the experimental condition, the two questions will be related to death or to an important exam. Participants will have to write their answers for each of the two questions directly on the computer. One question will be answered on a dark grey glossy screen reflecting the participant’s face and another question will be answered on a light grey glossy screen not reflecting the participant’s face. The two different glossy screens will be used to assess self-awareness avoidance (see hereafter). The order of the two questions and the order of the glossy screen colors (dark grey vs. light grey) will be counter-balanced across participants. 
IV2: Participants will be randomly assigned to a cold or warm room. As previously mentioned, the two rooms will be very similar except for temperature. The heater of the experimental room will be turned on or off to create a hot or a cold environment, respectively. Room temperature will be systematically monitored before and after each experimental session to make sure that the two environments differ substantially from one another in terms of temperature (targeted temperature difference = about 5 °C).
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:
DV1: The first dependent variable is a measure of self-awareness avoidance. The first DV is a composite score corresponding to the mean difference between time spent writing on a dark grey glossy screen reflecting the participant’s face and the time spent writing on a light grey glossy screen not reflecting the participant’s face (see section B. 1). Higher scores indicate that the participants spent more time looking at the computer screen when it reflects their own image than they spent time looking at the computer screen when it does not reflect their image.  

DV2: The second dependent variable is a measure of worldview defense. The responses to the 5 items used to assess the evaluation of the pro-French essay author will be averaged. In the same way, the responses to the 5 items used to assess the evaluation of the anti-French essay author will be averaged. The DV2 is the mean difference between the global evaluation of the pro- and anti- French essay author. Higher scores indicate greater preference for the pro- vs. anti- French essay author.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question6c: The number of hypotheses is already determined and is limited, hence we will not use corrections for multiple tests.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question7c: Missing data will be omitted from our analyses by pairwise deletion.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question9c: We do not anticipate any data transformation.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question10c: If the residual distribution of our dependent variables (DV1 and DV2) differs from normality (as assessed by a Shapiro-Wilks test), we will use a non-parametric alternative to test our hypotheses, such as a Mann-Whitney test.
registration_responses.recommended-methods.procedure.question9b: The study will be stopped and restarted if the proportion of excluded participants is greater than 20%.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
The experiment will take place either in a cold room (no heater during winter) or a warm room (with a heater). The study will be presented as a study on personality traits (cover story). Participants will randomly be assigned to a 2 (Mortality Salience vs. Control) x 2 (Warm temperature vs. Cold temperature) between-participants design. Each of them will answer to one question while in a situation inducing self-awareness (dark grey screen covered with a transparent Plexiglas reflecting one’s face) and one question in a situation not eliciting self-awareness (light grey screen covered with a transparent Plexiglas not reflecting one’s face) and time spent for each of these situations will be subtracted to compose a score reflecting one’s avoidance of the situation eliciting self-awareness (the lower the score, the higher the motivation to escape from self-awareness). The two questions will either be related to their future death or to a future exam depending on the experimental condition. Experimenters will be blind to participants’ mortality salience condition (but not to room temperature). 
Mortality salience will be activated by two open-ended questions (e.g., Arndt et al., 1998; Greenberg, Simon, Harmon-Jones et al., 1995; Rosenblatt et al., 1989). Participants will be invited to write a short text regarding their emotions, thoughts and events related to their own death versus to an important exam. This task will be completed directly on the computer, using the keyboard to write sentences in response to the death- or exam-related questions. 
The two open-ended questions will be:

- Mortality condition: «Please briefly describe the emotions that the thought of your own death arouses in you» and «Jot down, as specifically as you can, what you think will happen to you physically as you die and once you are physically dead». 
OR 
- Exam condition: «Please briefly describe the emotions that the thought of an important exam arouses in you» and «Jot down, as specifically as you can, what you think will happen to you physically as you are in exam situation and once you have finished».

Self-awareness avoidance. We will assess self-awareness avoidance by using the reflection of the participant’s face on a dark grey (vs. Light grey) screen covered with a piece of Plexiglas (see https://osf.io/sp6nc/). Covering the surface of the screen with a piece of Plexiglas can turn the screen into a reflective mirror-like surface when the background color is dark, but not when using a light-colored background color. The Plexiglas will be totally integrated to the screen to reduce any suspicion from participants. We will use block randomization for background color, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two blocks: either light-dark, or dark-light.

Delay. The PANAS-X is a questionnaire used to measure positive and negative affects (e.g., Watson & Clark, 1994). This scale will be used as delay task, a distractor task to obtain a delay between mortality exposure and World View Defense Questionnaire. Research and theorizing suggests that worldview defense is larger after a delay (Burke, Martens, & Faucher, 2010). 

World View Questionnaire. The worldview defense measure will consist of two texts displaying opposite opinions regarding the French values (e.g. Burke et al., 2010). These two opposite worldviews will then be rated by the participant on 5 items (7-points scales) to assess the participant’s agreement with the essay and the participant’s likeability of the author of the essay.

For the research materials (experiment script and worldview questionnaire), see https://osf.io/yrd8x/
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
Time taken to answer to each question will be collected using Psychopy2 (Peirce et al., 2019). We will compute a composite score of the time spent answering to the question associated to a dark screen minus the time spent answering to the question associated to a light screen (thus, the higher the score, the longer the time taken to write on the dark screen in comparison to the light screen).

A worldview defense score will be calculated as the preference for the pro- vs. anti- French essay in a similar manner (by subtraction).
We will use 2 X 2 ANOVAs to test our hypotheses. Planned comparisons will be examined using LSD tests.

IV1: mortality salience (death-related thoughts vs. exam-related thoughts)
IV2: room temperature (cold vs. warm)
DV1: self-awareness avoidance (time taken to write on the dark screen in comparison to the light screen)
DV2: worldview defense (preference for the pro- vs. anti- French essay)

The experiment includes several measures aimed at determining if the intended conditions are met: the actual room temperature will be measured before and after each participant’s session to make sure that the two conditions differ significantly in terms of temperatures. Thermometer will be not visible for the participants. In addition, subjective temperature perception will be collected orally at the end of the experiment session.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Participants will be native French speakers.

Participants will be introductory students psychology from the University of Poitiers who will participate in exchange for course credits. All data will be collected with a computer, except for the worldview defense measure (paper and pencil task).

Our target sample size is 200 participants (50 participants per cell). Our key prediction is an interaction between mortality salience (death thoughts vs. control thoughts) and room temperature (cold vs. warm) in a 2 x 2 analysis of variance (ANOVA). The present study is exploratory and the expected effect size is unknown. However, this sample size (N = 200) provides adequate power (80%) to detect a significant interaction (p <.05) assuming an effect size of Cohen’s d = 0.40. This small-to-moderate effect size is comparable to the mean effect size in social psychology based on a meta-meta-analysis of 100 years of research (Richard, Bond, & Stokes-Zoota, 2003).

For a file related to our power analysis, see https://osf.io/5nybp/
Data collection will stop when N = 200.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
Participants failing to answer to at least one of the two questions displayed on the computer screen will be excluded from our analyses.

A cut-off of 2.5 MAD from the median will be used to exclude outliers (Leys, Ley, Klein, Bernard, & Licata, 2013).

attributes.title: From Parochialism to an Inclusive City: Effects of a Film Intervention
attributes.description: We investigate the impact of a short pro-diversity film on in-group favoritism

q1.value: From Parochialism to an Inclusive City: Effects of a Film Intervention - Study 2

q3.value:
In this online experiment we investigate the impact of a short pro-diversity film on in-group favoritism among people living in Utrecht province. The film was modelled after the Danish film "All That We Share", but translated to the local (Utrecht) context. The punch line is "Utrecht, that's what we are together!" ("Utrecht, dat zijn we samen!")
Participants in the experimental condition watch the film, and then answer questions about their feelings towards having contact with the in-group and out-groups (i.e., to what extent thinking about contact makes them feel safe, comfortable, trusted, threatened, on their guard, and distant).

Participants in the universal film condition watch a film that is identical to the experimental film in terms of sound and vision, except for the voice-over which talks about people in general instead of Utrecht specifically. The punch line is "We share more than we know!" ("We delen meer dan we denken!").

Participants in the no film condition answer the same questions about their feelings towards having contact with the in-group and out-groups, but without watching the film first.

q4.value: We expect that in-group favoritism (i.e., feeling relatively positive about having contact with the in-group compared to having contact with out-groups) is higher in the no film condition than in the two film conditions (combined).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The experiment has a between-participants design with three conditions: local film, universal film, and no film. Participants will be randomly assigned to conditions.

q9.value: We will use block randomization with block size 9, which will result in approximately equal sample sizes in each of the three experimental conditions

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We draw data from the LISS panel, a probability-based (not self-selection) panel of currently (January 2020) approximately 4,500 households who fill out questionnaires every month via the Internet.  The address samples for recruitment and recruitment have been drawn from the population register in collaboration with Statistics Netherlands. LISS guarantees a high response and a representative sample.

In the past two years, the average response of the LISS panel was equal to 79%. Panel members receive € 2.50 for participating in this experiment, for a time investment of   ten minutes. Data will be collected between March and May, 2020.

For this study, only the residents of the province of Utrecht will be approached. To optimize the net response, we will draw from the CentER panel in addition to the LISS panel.

The CentERpanel consists of approximately 1,500 households and, like the LISS panel, is based on a probability sample. Panel members in the CentER panel complete questionnaires every two weeks.

q13.value: We hope to recruit at least 381 participants from Utrecht. LISS predicts they will be able to recruit 400 participants.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal is to obtain at least .80 power to detect an effect of partial eta-squared = .025 (f = .16)

question.value: We manipulate which film the participants see. The three conditions are: Local Film, Universal Film, No Film

Our main dependent variable is in-group favoritism. We record participants’ agreement with statements about their feelings toward their own group and towards other groups, whereby ‘own group’ refers to the group to which they identify, and ‘other groups’ refers to groups they do not identify with. The own-group statement reads “When I think about contact with my OWN group I feel...” followed by three positive and three negative emotions: safe; comfortable; familiar; threatened; on guard; and distant. For each emotion, participants indicate their agreement on 5-point Likert scales ranging from 1 (Strongly disagree) to 5 (Strongly agree). Then, they indicate their feelings towards the other groups by responding to the statement “When I think about contact with OTHER groups I feel...” in a similar way. In-group favoritism will be calculated by subtracting, for the positive emotions, the scores of the out-group from the score of the in-group, and for the negative emotions, the scores of the in-group from the score of the out-group. Then, we average these difference scores to obtain the in-group favoritism score. 

Other measures include: 

Perceptions of the film: Participants in the film conditions indicate to what extent the film is about Utrecht (manipulation check), to what extent they feel they are the intended audience of the film, whether they feel addressed by the film, and whether they think the film addresses universal human values. These perceptions are measured to explore potential differences between perceptions of the local film and the universal film.

Perceived group portrayal: Participants respond to four statements indicating how they think the groups are portrayed in the film. The items are designed, respectively, to measure the extent to which participants perceive that the film portrays the groups as different (Difference), the same (Similarity), as separate individuals (Individuals), or as different groups belonging to a larger in-group (Dual identity).

Mood: participants indicate to what extent they feel good, positive, bad, negative, moved and touched. Mood is measured to explore mood as potential mediator of the effects of the film(s).

In-group identification. Participants indicate how much they feel connected with their own group on a scale ranging from 1 (hardly) to 5 (very strongly).

Diversity attitude: Participants indicate to what extent they are generally proponents or opponents of a society that allows differences in culture and lifestyle, on a scale ranging from 1 (strong opponent) to 5 (strong proponent).
See previous textbox

We will use a between-participants ANOVA to test the omnibus effect of condition on in-group favoritism. Then, we use Helmert Contrast to test whether the mean in the no film condition differs from the mean of the two film conditions (combined)

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the Helmert Contrast tests suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q24.value:
We explore whether the effect of the local film (i.e., targeted at the respective city) on reducing in-group favoritism is equal, smaller or larger that the universal film (i.e., targeted at people in general), and whether the two films affect in-group favoritism via similar of different psychological processes. 
We also explore how the perceived group portrayal (e.g., similarity, individuals, dual identity) predict in-group favoritism. We test potential mediators (e.g., perceptions of the film, mood, group portrayal) as mediators of the effect of the film(s) on ingroup-favoritism.

attributes.title: Language bias in surveying bilingual Asians in North America
attributes.description: This project examines whether language of interview affects bilingual Asian Americans' and Canadians' responses to questions related to race

q2.value:
H1: Bilingual Chinese and Punjabis who take surveys in Chinese/Punjabi are more likely to report fears about racial discrimination in Canada than those who interview in English/French.

H2: Bilingual Chinese and Punjabis who take surveys in Chinese/Punjabi are more likely to report experiences with racial discrimination in Canada than those who interview in English/French.

H3: Bilingual Chinese and Punjabis who take surveys in Chinese/Punjabi are less likely to report a sense of belonging in Canada than those who interview in English/French.

H4: Bilingual Chinese are more likely to report fears about racial discrimination in Canada due to COVID-19 than bilingual Punjabis.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a between subject design. Self-identified Chinese and Punjabi participants answer two questions (in English) that assess their fluency in simplified/traditional Chinese or Punjabi. Participants who consider themselves fluent in these Asian languages are randomized into treatment or control. Participants in the treatment group answer the next three questions in either Chinese or Punjabi; participants in the control group answer the same questions in English.

q7.value: I will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two equally sized, predetermined blocks. Qualtrics survey design randomly assigns participants to the blocks.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: The survey experiment I designed is part of a larger survey run by researchers at University of Toronto. I've been told they aim to field the survey by the evening of March 26, 2020. However, I do not know if they met that start date, and I have not checked the enrollment statistics in Qualtrics. The researchers will notify me when the data collection is complete.

question.value: Subjects are undergraduate students at the University of Toronto. They receive extra credit marks for participating in the study. For the purpose of this project, I focus on responses of Chinese and Punjabi students. However, students from any racial background is eligible to participate in the study.

q11.value: My target sample size is 250 participants.

q13.value: The data collection will complete by the end of spring 2020 semester at the University of Toronto. If there are not enough participants by then, I will try to run another round of the experiment during the Fall 2020 semester.

question.value: I manipulate the language that participants take the survey. This is a binary variable where 1=Chinese/Punjabi, 0=English.

Fear of discrimination (outcome): Using a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 is not worried at all and 5 is very worried, how worried participant is of becoming the victim of a crime in Canada because of hatred towards their ethnicity/race due to COVID-19.

Experiences of discrimination (outcome): Whether participant experienced racial discrimination in Canada in the past 5 years. 

Belonging (outcome): Participant's sense of belonging in Canada

Covariates: generation status, gender, political ideology

I will run separate models for Chinese and Punjabi participants. I will use multiple regression to analyze each one of the three outcome variables. Since "fear of discrimination" and "belonging" are ordered on a 5 point scale, I will conduct a Brant test of proportionality. If these two variables are indeed ordered, I will implement ordered logit models. Since "reports of discrimination" is a binary variable, I will implement logit models.

q18.value: All categorical and continuous variables will be rescaled on a unit interval. I do not plan on transforming any categorical or continuous variables into binary forms.

q19.value: I will use the standard p<0.5 criteria, and I will use two tailed tests.

q20.value: I will verify that each participant answered each of the three outcome variables. There is also a timer on the questions, so participants who answer them in an unreasonably short amount of time will be excluded. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q21.value: Subjects who do not provide a response to one outcome variable will be excluded from analysis for that particular outcome only. They will still be included in analysis of outcome variables they do answer.

registration_responses.q20: I will verify that each participant answered each of the three outcome variables. There is also a timer on the questions, so participants who answer them in an unreasonably short amount of time will be excluded. Outliers will be included in the analysis.
registration_responses.q21: Subjects who do not provide a response to one outcome variable will be excluded from analysis for that particular outcome only. They will still be included in analysis of outcome variables they do answer.
registration_responses.q6.question: This is a between subject design. Self-identified Chinese and Punjabi participants answer two questions (in English) that assess their fluency in simplified/traditional Chinese or Punjabi. Participants who consider themselves fluent in these Asian languages are randomized into treatment or control. Participants in the treatment group answer the next three questions in either Chinese or Punjabi; participants in the control group answer the same questions in English.
registration_responses.q10.question: Subjects are undergraduate students at the University of Toronto. They receive extra credit marks for participating in the study. For the purpose of this project, I focus on responses of Chinese and Punjabi students. However, students from any racial background is eligible to participate in the study.
registration_responses.q14.question: I manipulate the language that participants take the survey. This is a binary variable where 1=Chinese/Punjabi, 0=English.
registration_responses.q15.question:
Fear of discrimination (outcome): Using a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 is not worried at all and 5 is very worried, how worried participant is of becoming the victim of a crime in Canada because of hatred towards their ethnicity/race due to COVID-19.

Experiences of discrimination (outcome): Whether participant experienced racial discrimination in Canada in the past 5 years. 

Belonging (outcome): Participant's sense of belonging in Canada

Covariates: generation status, gender, political ideology
registration_responses.q17.question: I will run separate models for Chinese and Punjabi participants. I will use multiple regression to analyze each one of the three outcome variables. Since "fear of discrimination" and "belonging" are ordered on a 5 point scale, I will conduct a Brant test of proportionality. If these two variables are indeed ordered, I will implement ordered logit models. Since "reports of discrimination" is a binary variable, I will implement logit models.

attributes.title: Third Party Punishment Proportionality as Determinant of Perceived Warmth, Competence and Potential Social Role
attributes.description:
Contrary to the view that third-party punishment is entirely altruistic, recent research suggests that punishers gain reputational benefits from the seemingly selfless act of punishing. This implies that third-party punishment constitutes a signaling mechanism, and that punishment carries key information about the punisher. Nevertheless, how the signal is determined has not been fully examined.   
The signaling function of punishing could depend on an essential component of third-party punishment, its proportionality. In this study, I will test how severity, a fundamental constituent of proportionality, influences the perceived warmth, competence and potential social role (i.e. leader vs friend) of the punisher. Likewise, I will evaluate how proportionality influences the perceived motivations of the punishers (i.e. genuine moral concern vs motives of self interest).

q2.value:
1.  A Third party punisher's perceived warmth and competence vary as a function of the level of punishment severity (i.e. disproportionately lenient, proportional and disproportionately severe).
2. The attributed motives for Third Party Punishing vary depending on proportionality and  mediate the perceived warmth and competence traits.
3. The social role assigned to the third party punisher varies as a function of the punishment's proportionality.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Subjects will read 4 different vignettes corresponding to 4 different scenarios of everyday third party punishment. Consequently this is a between subjects study with a 3x4 design with 3 levels for the severity factor (low severity, proportional and high severity) and four levels for the scenario factor (stutter scenario, vegan scenario, eggs scenario and cutting in line scenario).

q7.value: Each participant will be randomly assigned to 4 of the 12 possible severity-scenario combinations.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: The data is sitting in Qualtrics in its raw form and has not been accessed by anyone. Only I and William Jimenez-Leal have access to it. In Prolific we set a limit of 746 observations and correspondingly in Qualtrics there are 748 recorded responses but we still don't know how many of those are usable data points, which ones are incomplete, what their distribution is or if there were any issues with the completion of the task. No more responses will be collected at this point.

question.value: Prolific platform, only adult individuals who are fluent in English

q12.value: An a priori power analysis (with a minimum detectable effect of 0.4, an alpha level of 0.05 and a 0.9 power aiming to reasonably reduce Type 2 errors) rendered a total sample size of N = 475.  However, given the novel nature of the research, the possibility of incomplete responses and timing out, as well as the need to analyze interactions, we elevated that number to 746.

question.value:
The severity variable was manipulated thusly:

STUTTER SCENARIO

Low: Fred makes eye contact with his colleague and shakes his head in disapproval. 
Proportional: Fred tells his colleague, in a loud enough voice so that half the people in the coffee shop can hear, that making fun of someone’s stutter and posting an offensive cartoon is not OK and tears the cartoon down.
High: Fred tells his colleague, in a very loud voice so that everyone at the coffee shop can hear, that making fun of someone’s stutter and posting an offensive cartoon is not OK and tears the cartoon down, then sends an email to everyone at work telling them about the incident and posts a picture of his colleague on Twitter accusing him of being a horrible human being.

VEGAN SCENARIO

Low: Harry makes eye contact with the man and shakes his head in disapproval.
Proportional: Harry tells the man that deceiving people about what they are eating is not OK, then tells the host of the barbecue what the man did and asks the man to leave the barbecue.
High: Harry tells the man that deceiving people about what they are eating is not OK, then tells the host of the barbecue what the man did and asks the man to leave the barbecue. Afterwards, he hires a lawyer and convinces the woman to file a lawsuit against the man.

EGGS SCENARIO

Low: Martha makes eye contact with the girl and shakes her head in disapproval. 
Proportional: Martha confronts the girl and tells her that throwing eggs at houses is not OK.
High: Martha confronts the girl and tells her that throwing eggs at houses is not OK. After the incident and every day for the following month, Martha looks for the girl while she is waiting for her school bus and tells her that she should be ashamed of herself.

CUTTING IN LINE SCENARIO

Low: Jennifer makes eye contact with the boy and shakes her head in disapproval.
Proportional: Jennifer tells the boy that cutting in line is not OK and makes him go back to the end of the line so that he waits for his turn like everybody else.
High: Jennifer tells the boy that cutting in line is not OK, then takes him out of the line and makes him stand in a corner for 15 minutes while he watches the other children playing before he can go again.

The dependent variables are:
1. Rated Warmth 
2. Rated Competence
3. Rated Motivation
4. Rated Social Role

For the Warmth index:

a)	trustworthiness (1 = extremely untrustworthy, 7 = extremely trustworthy)
b)	friendliness (1 = extremely unfriendly, 7 = extremely friendly)
c)	warmth (1 = extremely cold, 7 = extremely warm)
d)	kindness (1 = extremely unkind, 7 = extremely kind)
e)	niceness (1 = extremely mean, 7 = extremely nice)

For the Competence index:

a)	dominance (1 = extremely nondominant, 7 = extremely dominant)
b)	competence (1 = extremely incompetent, 7 = extremely competent)
c)	confidence (1 = extremely unconfident, 7 = extremely confident)
d)	capability (1 = extremely incapable, 7 = extremely capable)
e)	efficacy (1 = extremely ineffective, 7 = extremely effective).   

For the Genuine Moral Motivation index:

the punisher acted out of...

a)	genuine moral concerns (1 = definitely not, 7 = definitely yes) 
b)	moral principle (1 = definitely not, 7 = definitely yes)
c)	a genuine moral stand (1 = definitely not, 7 = definitely yes)

For the Self-Interest Motive index:

a)	personal self-interest (1 = definitely not, 7 = definitely yes)
b)	what was good for them personally (1 = definitely not, 7 = definitely yes)
c)	selfish reasons (1 = definitely not, 7 = definitely yes)

For the Social Role index: 

a)	would make a good leader (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree)
b)	has the potential to be a good leader (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree)
c)	shows leadership (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree)
d)	would make a good friend (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree)
e)	has the potential to be a good friend (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree)
f)	shows the qualities of a friend (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree)

I will make use of general linear models where main effects and interactions will be examined.  Warmth and dominance will be firstly analyzed in isolation and compared by both proportionality and scenario. The entire set of five items aimed at measuring warmth will be analyzed and a Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated to ensure that they can be used in conjunction as an indicator of warmth perception. The same procedure will be run for the items of the competence perception indicator, as well as the friend predilection and leader predilection indicators. As for the motive attributions, the self-interest items will be reverse coded and averaged into a single composite along with the moral motives items. The main analysis will allow me to test if there are statistically significant differences for the three severity levels with regards to: 
1.	trustworthiness
2.	dominance 
3.	warmth
4.	competence 
5.	motive attribution
6.	friend preference
7.	leader preference 
In addition, a mediation analysis will be conducted to assess the causal mechanism of attributed motives on person perceptions (i.e. warmth and competence).

attributes.title: SES Dissimilarity-Centrality
attributes.description: Two-part field study with employees and supervisors investigating the interactive effect of employee-supervisor SES dissimilarity and SES identity centrality.

q1.value: Hana Johnson, Fong Highberger Keng, Yunhyung Chung, Chak Fu LAM, Elizabeth Umphress, Wen Wu

q2.value:
1. For path analysis: The positive effect of actual employee-supervisor SES identity dissimilarity on perceived employee-supervisor SES identity dissimilarity is strengthened when identity centrality and identity threat are higher.
1a. The indirect effect of actual employee-supervisor SES identity dissimilarity on dependent variables (positive effect on: information elaboration, supervisor deviance, unethical pro-supervisor behaviors, conflict, ostracism; negative effect on: sense of power, supervisor identification, supervisor satisfaction, commitment to supervisor, supervisor trust, interactional justice, friendship, subordinate commitment, performance, supportive voice, challenging voice, helping behaviors, leadership emergence) is mediated by perceived employee-supervisor SES identity dissimilarity and moderated by identity centrality and identity threat, such that the indirect effects are strengthened when the moderators are higher.

2. For polynomial regression: Incongruence between actual employee SES identity and supervisor SES identity is positively related to perceived employee-supervisor SES identity dissimilarity. Perceived employee-supervisor SES identity dissimilarity will decrease as actual employee SES increases toward actual leader SES and will gradually increase as actual employee SES exceeds actual leader SES.
2a. SES identity centrality moderates the relationship between actual SES identity incongruence and perceived employee-supervisor SES identity dissimilarity such that as SES identity centrality increases, the positive relationship between actual SES incongruence and perceived employee-supervisor SES dissimilarity is strengthened.
2b. SES identity threat moderates the relationship between actual SES identity incongruence and perceived employee-supervisor SES identity dissimilarity such that as SES identity threat increases, the positive relationship between actual SES incongruence and perceived employee-supervisor SES dissimilarity is strengthened.
2c. Perceived employee-supervisor SES identity dissimilarity will mediate the interactive relationship between actual SES identity dissimilarity and identity centrality or identity threat on our dependent variables.

3. Exploratory: COVID-19 fear or anxiety is an antecedent to SES identity threat in the hypotheses above.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Cross-sectional design with one survey fielded with employees at Time 2 and and another survey fielded with supervisors at Time 2 (4 weeks later than Time 1). There is no manipulation or randomization.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
1. We are inviting online MBA students who are enrolled in a program at a large university in the Western U.S. to participate in a survey themselves and to recruit their supervisor to participate in a survey.
2. The instructor of the core required online MBA class will announce the participation in the study as an extra credit opportunity. Detailed information about the study will be posted on the class’ website. 
3. The MBA students emails one of the investigators with their email address and LinkedIn profile and the email address and LinkedIn profile of their supervisor. The investigator emails the survey link to the MBA student. 4 weeks later, the investigatory emails the survey link to the supervisor.
4. MBA students receive 1% of their overall class grade as extra credit for providing the email address/LinkedIn profile for their supervisors and themselves, and completing the employee survey. The MBA student and supervisor each earn an entry into a drawing to win a $200 Amazon gift card (10 winners) or $100 Amazon gift card (10 winners) upon completion of their respective surveys. The MBA student receives an additional 4 entries into the drawing if both the employee & supervisor complete their surveys. The MBA student will also receive a small pendant with the school's logo.
5. Due to IRB restrictions, only students living and working in the U.S. may participate.
6. The study timeline: survey launches March 30, 2020.

q11.value: There are approximately 500 online MBA students offered in the class for which extra credit is being offered. Each unit is an employee-supervisor dyad. So we will only be analyzing data for which the employee and his/her supervisor completes the survey.

q12.value: Our sample size is based on how many students are enrolled in the core online MBA class.

q13.value: The class runs from March 9, 2020 to April 26, 2020 so students may participate any time during that time period. The supervisor survey will be sent 4 weeks after the employee survey so it’s possible for the last supervisor survey to be emailed as late as May 22, 2020. We will allow supervisors up to 2 weeks to complete their survey so our estimate is that data collection will end mid-June 2020.

question.value: Not applicable

Note: see appendix for all survey items & citations for each scale)
1. Predictors: “Actual self-supervisor dissimilarity” will be calculated in one of 2 ways depending on the type of analysis:
1a. Using path analysis: Calculated as the absolute difference between the employee and supervisor’s rating on the 1-item “social status” measure. Then divide the individual discrepancy score by respective standard deviation.
1b. Using polynomial regression:  “Actual employee SES identity” and "Actual supervisor SES identity" will be the rating on the 1-item “social status” measure for employee and supervisor, respectively.

2. Moderators: 
2a. Identity centrality: mean of 10 items focused on “social status”
2b. Identity threat: mean of 3 items focused on “social status”
2c. COVID-19 fear: mean of 5 items
2d. COVID-19 anxiety: mean of 6 items

3. Mediators:
3a. Perceived employee-supervisor SES dissimilarity: 4 items focused on  “social status”

4. Dependent variables:
4a. Sense of power: 8 items
4b. Information elaboration: 3 items
4c. Supervisor identification: 6 items
4d. Supervisor satisfaction: 3 items
4e. Commitment to supervisor: 3 items
4f. Supervisor trust: 4 items
4g. Interactional justice: 4 items
4h. Supervisor deviance: 3 items
4i. Unethical pro-supervisor behaviors: 3 items 
4j. Relationship Conflict: 4 items
4k. Friendship: 5 items
4l. Subordinate commitment: 3 items
4m. Job performance: 5 items
4n. Supportive voice: 5 items
4o. Challenging voice: 7 items
4p. Helping behaviors: 3 items
4q. Ostracism: 4 items
4r. Leader emergence: 4 items

5. Control variables: Control in all analyses: Depending on our sample size and the complexity of analyses, we may have to first test to see if control variables below have an effect on our variables of interest and only control for the variables which do have an effect (due to adequate power concerns). If sample size is large enough, we can accommodate all control variables. 

5a. Gender dissimilarity: Coded gender as “same” (0) or “different” (1). Then divided the individual discrepancy score by respective standard deviation.
5b. Age dissimilarity: Absolute difference in age in years between employee & supervisor. Then divided the individual discrepancy score by respective standard deviation.
5c. Dyadic tenure
5d. # of minutes interact with supervisor each week
5e. Employee level within organization
5g. Belief that supervisor is of higher social class than employee or not.

6. Also control in analyses with “supportive voice” or “challenging voice” as the DV:
6a. Individual psychological safety: 3 items
6b. Voice efficacy: 3 items
We will calculate either dissimilarity or the average of items as specified above for each variable in the “measured variables” section.

1. We will use path analysis in Mplus to test each path analysis hypothesis.
2. We will exclude all participants who do not pass the 2 attention checks embedded in the survey. We will test each moderated mediation hypothesis separately.
3. We will use R to test each moderated mediation hypothesis in our path analysis and generate 95% confidence intervals for the indirect effects. 
4. We will use polynomial regression in Mplus to test the polynomial regression hypotheses.
5. To test the mediation and moderated mediation hypotheses from the polynomial regression analyses, we will use the block variable approach as recommended by Edwards and Cable (2009).  
6. We will conduct simple slopes analyses for significant interactions in the path analysis.

q18.value: For polynomial regression, actual SES identity and the moderators, identity centrality and identity threat, will be centered at the midpoint of the scale as recommended by Shanock, Baran, Gentry, Pattison, & Heggestad, 2010.

q19.value:
1. For path analysis, we will consider the p-value to be significant if < .05, and marginal if between .05-.10. We will use two tailed tests.
2. For path analysis, we will consider mediation to be supported if the 95%CI does not include 0.
3. For polynomial regression, a u-shaped relationship will be supported if the curvature along the incongruence line is significantly positive.
4. For polynomial regression, the strengthening of a u-shaped relationship will be supported if the coefficient for the curvature along the incongruence line gets larger and more positive as the moderator increases.
5. For polynomial regression, we will consider mediation to be significantly supported if the p-values for the relationship between the interaction and the mediator and the relationship between the mediator and the dependent variable are < .05 and marginally significant if between .05-.10. We will use two tailed tests.

q20.value:
1. Data will be excluded if both the employee and supervisor do not complete their respective surveys.
2. Data will be excluded for participants who have failed attention checks and for those who have no variance in responses (e.g., answers “3” for all items).
3. Data will be excluded if the employee and supervisor have not worked together for at least 6 months.
4. We will exclude outliers on dyadic tenure and interaction with supervisor if the participant is more than 3 standard deviations from the mean on either variable.

q21.value: Missing data will be specified as missing within SPSS and Mplus. Both use listwise deletion.

q22.value:
1. Perceived employee-supervisor deep level dissimilarity (5 items) as a mediator instead of Perceived employee-supervisor SES dissimilarity
2. Control for Perceived employee-team dissimilarity: 1 item for “social status”
3. Control for COVID-19 impact: change in % of job conducted remotely, change in # of minutes interact with supervisor each week in-person, satisfaction with telecommuting, disruption of work as a result of COVID-19, whether someone close to employee has been diagnosed with COVID-19
